awd_abstract_narration:
Smith
DMS-1008396

     The project aims to better understand the role of
inertia-gravity waves in two highly relevant problems in
geophysical fluid dynamics: (i) the origin of observed ocean wave
spectra, and (ii) tropical cyclogenesis and the preconditioned
state for the development of hurricanes.  Both studies involve a
similar dynamical core, namely, the rotating Boussinesq equations
with strong stratification.  Previous theoretical progress toward
understanding ocean spectra has been made by considering exact
three-wave resonances under the weak turbulence paradigm.  Here
the investigator studies new partial-differential equation models
including all three-wave interactions, thus capturing more
complete physics.  Effects of rotation, stratification and
hydrostatic balance are deduced analytically through explicitly
derived, nonlinear coupling coefficients.  Numerical simulations
characterize energy spectra and generation of shear.  Adding
simplified cloud dynamics (condensation and evaporation of water)
to the Boussinesq core allows for investigation of the hurricane
embryo.  The latter project involves numerical implementation and
exploration of a minimal, active moisture model including fast
waves, extending recent work using imposed heat sources to
incorporate moist processes within the context of balanced models
(excluding fast waves). 

     Inertia-gravity waves result from the earth's rotation and
density stratification of the atmosphere and oceans.  The effects
of inertia-gravity waves are varied, for example, waves can
self-organize to form large-scale coherent structures widely
observed in nature, such as cyclones and/or anticyclones,
east-west jets, and horizontal shear layers.  Yet there are
critically important flows for which the dynamical role of
inertia-gravity waves is yet to be described by a fully
self-consistent mathematical theory.  The project addresses two
such fundamental application problems using a combination of
analytical and numerical calculations: (i) the scale distribution
of wave energy in the oceans, and (ii) tropical cyclogenesis
(also known as the hurricane embryo problem).  In the oceans,
tidal and wind forcing generate internal gravity-wave breaking,
ultimately establishing the balance between small-scale mixing
and global circulation.  For the problem of tropical
cyclogenesis, previous mathematical models have filtered out the
fast waves, and there is much to learn about the role of fast
waves for the emergence and stability of low-altitude cyclonic
vertical vorticity, leading ultimately to the formation of a
hurricane.  The topics involve ocean mixing and ocean-atmosphere
interactions, which are important factors in climate.

The goal of the project was to further investigate the formation of coherent structures in fluid systems related to geophysical flows, such as cyclones and/or anticyclones, east-west jets, and rising plumes.  One Ph.D. student and one postdoctoral researcher were partially supported by the project, promoting the interdisciplinary training of young mathematicians, with the ability to use techniques of applied mathematics to attack problems related to weather and climate.  

In the earth's atmosphere and oceans, there exist a multitude of physical processes that may lead to structure formation, for example, self-organization of wave motions generated by flow over topography, organization of turblence by large-scale winds, the moisture cycle of condensation and evaporation of water, and the diurnal heating cycle, to name a few.  Our project involved idealized studies to isolate fundamental mechanisms for structure generation associated with some of the possible environmental conditions.

During the first part of the funding period, we focused on flows including the effects of inertia-gravity waves, which are the waves generated by the earth's rotation and stable density stratification (density/temperature decreasing with height). Inertia-gravity waves were investigated analytically and numerically in so-called dry flows without the effects of water substance (e.g. clouds and rain).  Among other results, we demonstrated that a model including only inertia-gravity waves generates strong vertically sheared horizontal flows, such as found in the earth's stratosphere.  The model of three-wave interactions is a generalization of weak-turbulence theory including a special subset of  `resonant'  three-wave interactions, but the latter cannot generate these strong horizontal flows. Thus our model represents a significant step in understanding the dynamics of rotating and stratified systems.

Broadening the scope of our numerical computations, we later added the ability to simulate moist flows including phase changes of water: condensation of water vapor to form liquid water in the form of clouds and rain, and evaporation of rain water to form water vapor.  A numerical investigation of moist dynamics was aimed at understanding the combined effects of inertia-gravity waves, low-altitude wind shear, and low-altitude excess moisture, such as might be found above a warm ocean.  When excess moisture is present in localized patches, latent heat release from condensation leads to rising plumes of relatively warm air which inherit the cyclonic vorticity of the earth's background rotation.  These plumes resemble the vortical hot towers observed in both cyclogenesis and mature hurricanes. In our idealized simulations with localized, low-altitude moisture forcing, small-scale cyclonic hot towers could merge together to form larger moist vortices, reminiscent of cyclogenesis.  Weak low-altitude shear was observed to enhance the merger process, while strong low-altitude shear altered the monopole structure of the individual towers and thus prevented the organization of larger-scale moist vortices.  Our work linked the transition from monopole to dipole structure of rising plumes with shear inhibition of cyclogenesis.
